replies.body: Entire roles would be banned out if there were 10 bans. Sometimes there aren't even 10 meta picks. For competitive it would be a disaster, players could be completely banned out with 5 targeted at them.
For competitive, other teams would have to have champion pools as deep as Unicorns of Love. I personally don't see that as a bad thing.

Even then, Riot could just keep the 6 bans for ranked 5v5 teams and pro play, but give soloQ 10 bans with 1 per player. Now each player in SoloQ can ban what they don't want to go up against, LCS and ranked 5v5 is not touched, and I'd say at least 10 people are happy.

And if for some reason an entire soloQ lobby bans out 10 supports, then I guess the whole lobby wanted a weird game.

The champions selected are upon a few of those that will get banned from majority from time to time. {{champion:113}} also being on my list.

This allows for 4 more bans and which leaves us with 111 champions still to chose from. At least to those who have over 60 get 50 to chose from.

So your opinion is that versatility and champion pool is what makes players good. It's a valid reason, but there are some people like me that don't think like you. The thing is that Unicorns of Love demonstrated you can win with off-meta picks if you make the game chaotic enough. And all of that with six bans.

10 bans would make the tier 2 the meta and the tier 1 just simply banned. It's not the solution IMO.
you're assuming people would just ban top tier picks, which is definitely not the case if you look at ban rates. sure they are up there but they're definitely nowhere close to exclusive.

I think that there are two alternatives: They would ban either a complete role or all top tiers.

In soloQ midlane would be unplayable because they would never get their mains. In competitive play either they have a star player who would be completely denied or the whole team would not get their mains.

If you have a diverse champion pool, you can do better than someone with the bare minimum of champs.
In my opinion, at least.

Specializing is what makes you be godlike at some champions. 99% of people can't just play whatever and get the same result. The sickest outplays come after hours and hours invested in playing one champion, not from generalists.

Sure, but if you only invest your time into the same 5 champions (in this scenario) such as Jarvan IV, Brand, Caitlyn, Xerath, and Jayce, and if those 5 are banned, then you don't really have a broad champion pool that let's you have multiple options when someone is picked/banned.
Now, there ARE going to be champions who you will be naturally better with, and there are always going to be the ones who just don't click for you as they do for other players.
All in all, the easiest way to "outplay" someone is to just know what to do with the abilities, as well as not go too balls deep into something that's just gonna kill you anyway.

I think that the whole point that I'm trying to defend throughout this thread is that IMO deep champion pools and versatility is not what makes a player good. It has to be proven that they can keep some sort of level outside their "mains", but it shouldn't be tested 24/7.

Yeah, I see what you're saying.
The thing is, if you don't have an expansive champion pool, then you might run into MANY match ups that you have no clue what the other champion can do, damage and timing in mind... Basically, think of this as if you are going against Heimerdinger for the first time... It's going to be absolute HELL because you don't know how to fight around his turrets, or even how to fight Heimerdinger himself, or even underestimating the damage that all three of his turrets can pour onto you.
If I kept my champion pool to my few favorites:
Heimerdinger, Jinx, Sona, Sion, Teemo
Putting that into account, I wouldn't really have a good knowledge of how many of the other champions worked, besides testing them during the free rotation.
The pros are good at what they do simply because they know what they're doing, and they know how the other champions work so that they don't make stupid mistakes over and over again.
However, I do understand what you're saying.
you know what LCS players have? Deep champion pools. That makes them better. Why do you want to not be better?

Do they? Are you sure? There are plenty of them that are heavily denied when they get directly banned.

Good players are so because they are good. Versatility and deep champion pools is a luxury of the best ones.

as pros, they are *paid to adapt to the game*. That is literally their job. If the ban pool is increased, they are still going to be far better than you and I, not just mechanically but in terms of strategy, positioning and timing, so we can see equal skill on more champs because that is their JOB to stay good. Do you tell your boss "nope we can't raise the requirements on this project because I won't be good at it anymore"? No, you get fired for that.

They are _paid to be the best_. There is no reward at the end of a loss if you played an off-meta pick. Also, the game is not made for those in the LCS, it is made for 90% of players who can't reach that level of greatness.

If I'm in soloQ and I can't play my 2 favourite champions because they are strong (not even the best) just because between 10 bans there is a lot of probability that they are banned, I won't have that much fun.

Because I don't change my favorites by who is played in LCS. 12 months ago I would have had a hard time picking Syndra because she was suddenly so many people's favorite. Now all those people who claimed she was their favorite or main favor other champions. I can get her every game again. Funny how that works.

Not saying you are that way. But the vast majority of this community is. As is obvious by needing bans in the first place. And I have no sympathy for those individuals.

> So your opinion is that versatility and champion pool is what makes players good.

No. But it makes games more interesting.

Bronze V games are very interesting and exciting. 55-67 is crazy.

High level of play doesn't usually come from odd picks, but from deep understanding of the game and the champion. That is acquired through hours of play and "maining" those champions.

I'm not even looking for "odd picks".
It just gets old watching the same 15ish champions played they same way by the same people every game for most of the year.
That's why UoL is making a stir. It's not that they're better; but they're more diverse in their champ pool and tactics. Makes watching them for more than 2 games not boring (or at least, less so).

I don't see how this is a problem, and frankly the fact that this is somehow considered a legitimate argument is retarded.

The problem isn't that a role will be banned out its that the team that picks first get a HUGE advantage by picking the most dominant champion in their role. A simple example would be to ban cait, corki, twich, draven, kogmaw and then just first pick Jinx. Now there are other adc's you can play but none that are going to match Jinx late game or beat her in laneing phase.
